--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "martin_pyka" <martin.pyka@...> wrote:
>
> >=
 Hi Martin, yes I think actually from my understanding of biology that bila=
teral symmetry in the human line, which starts with the flatworm long ago, =
was indeed evolved from an earlier radial symmetry.  But my point is more a=
bout how a regularity (or irregularity) was *preserved* as opposed to how i=
t was *achieved*. No matter how a particular organizational principle comes=
 about (now I'm being more careful to avoid suggesting it's more or less re=
gular than before), the problem is that there is no reason for evolution to=
 reward and thereby preserve it in an objective setting when it's first dis=
covered.  So whether or not bilateral symmetry comes from a reduction in re=
gularity or an increase in regularity, if the first bilaterally symmetric i=
ndividual does not look very close to the final objective (and it most like=
ly does not) then it is likely to be selected out and lost by an objective-=
driven search.
> 
> This is now going to be slightly off-topic, but I would=
 like to add the following thoughts to your response: 
> I also see the pro=
blem that certain organizational principles (OPs) are hard to establish whe=
n their advantage becomes only apparent in the long run (if at all). Nevert=
heless, I think that the starting position of an evolutionary process can f=
acilitate or prevent the emergence of certain OPs. For example, starting wi=
th radial symmetry, I could imagine that the amount of possibilities to red=
uce symmetry offers far more chances to establish asymmetric patterns than =
the reduction from an asymmetric structure to a symmetric one. 
> 
> Martin=

>

I'm sure you're right that the currently-established OPs will bias the =
search towards or away from discovering certain kinds of OPs in the future.=
   But that's really a property of encoding bias (as opposed to a result of=
 selective pressure).  That's why encodings like CPPNs or other indirect en=
codings are important, because they make certain chains of OPs more easy to=
 establish.  But whether a particular statement is true, like whether it's =
more likely to go radial->bilateral than totally-asymmetric->bilateral, wil=
l depend a lot on the mathematical properties of the encoding.  So you real=
ly have to reason it out in terms of a particular encoding, like CPPNs, as =
opposed to only based evolutionary history observed in nature, though in so=
me cases the same reasoning would apply to both.

ken
